Now the constraints--

that evaluates to
either true or false. So they're either
satisfied or they're not. And the predicates
describe constraints.

And sometimes people call this
hard constraints or something like that because the semantics
is really, really simple.

The semantics is this-- if someone proposes an x and
one of these is violated,

and it doesn't matter
by how much, then it is completely unacceptable.

So that is the semantics

where constraints
